metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of airborne microwave radiometers (K&Ka bands) mission in the Binggou watershed flight zone on Mar. 30, 2008
metadata.description:
The dataset of airborne microwave radiometers (K&Ka) mission was obtained in the Binggou watershed flight zone on Mar. 30, 2008. 
     The frequency of K bands was 18.7 GHz at the nadir view angle without polarization; and the frequency of Ka band was 36.0 GHz with the scanning angle range ±12°. The plane took off at Zhangye airport at 12:43 (BJT) and landed at 15:44, along the scheduled 11 lines at the altitude about 5000m and speed about 220-250km/hr.  
     The raw data include microwave radiometer (L&K) data and GPS data;  K band was instantaneous non-imaging observation recorded in text, which will be converted into brightness temperatures according to the calibration coefficients (filed with raw data together) and Ka band was recorded hex text, and the latter are aircraft longitude, latitude and attitude. Moreover, based on the respective real-time clock log, observations by the microwave radiometer and GPS can be integrated to offer coordinates matching for the former. Yaw, flip, and pitch motions of aircraft were ignored due to the low resolution of microwave radiometer observations. Observation information can also be rasterized, as required, after calibration and coordinates matching. K band resolution (x) and footprint can be  approximately estimated as x=0.3H (H is relative flight height); for Ka the resolution was 39m.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the K&Ka band airborne microwave radiometer data collected over an ice ditch flight area?
Feature Specification.Answer: K band frequency 18.7GHz, zenith angle observation, no polarization information, Ka band frequency 36.0GHz, scanning imaging, vertical polarization observation, non-imaging, instantaneous observation, original hexadecimal text files, 24-degree scan range, 112 data points, GPS records, resolution for K band matches observation footprint, Ka band resolution 39m, calibration necessary, coordinate matching necessary.

Quantification.Question: What is the frequency of the K and Ka band microwave radiometers used in a dataset related to remote sensing in the Binggou region?

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of incorporating GPS data into microwave radiometer observations in terms of improving geolocation accuracy for remote sensing datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating GPS data into microwave radiometer observations allows for the precise matching of microwave observations with geographic coordinates, enhancing the geolocation accuracy of the datasets. This integration enables the assignment of accurate spatial information, even considering the effects of angle scanning in Ka-band data, leading to improved spatial resolution and usability of the dataset for remote sensing applications.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of collecting microwave radiometer data at K and Ka bands for observing the Binggou flight area, and how do these data contribute to understanding environmental or atmospheric phenomena?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose of collecting microwave radiometer data at K and Ka bands for observing the Binggou flight area is to gather precise measurements of brightness temperatures, which can be used to analyze environmental or atmospheric conditions. The K band data provide non-imaging observations, while the Ka band data offer imaging capabilities with a specific scanning range and polarization. These data contribute to understanding atmospheric phenomena by providing detailed information on microwave emissions from the surface, which can be used for environmental monitoring and analysis of physical processes in the atmosphere and surface interactions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What specific procedures are followed to collect and preprocess data from K&Ka band airborne microwave radiometers for generating usable products in remote sensing applications?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection involves flying an aircraft equipped with K&Ka band airborne microwave radiometers over the designated area. The K band operates at a frequency of 18.7GHz and performs nadir observations without polarization information, while the Ka band operates at a frequency of 36.0GHz and performs scanning imaging with vertical polarization within a ±12° scanning range. The aircraft flies at an altitude of approximately 5000m and a speed of 220-250 km/hr. The raw data consists of microwave radiometer data and GPS data. The K band data is recorded as instantaneous digital values in text files, while Ka band data is stored in hexadecimal text files and needs conversion to decimal for further processing. The GPS data logs the aircraft's latitude, longitude, and attitude parameters. To preprocess the data for usability, the digital values from the radiometer observations are converted to brightness temperature using calibration coefficients. The microwave observations are geographically matched with the GPS data by synchronizing their respective time stamps. The Ka band data requires additional processing to account for the angle scanning effect by assigning geographical coordinates to each of the 112 data points within the scanning range. Due to the coarse resolution of the microwave observations, the aircraft's yaw, roll, and pitch effects are generally ignored during data processing. After calibration and coordinate matching, the observation information can be rasterized, with the K band resolution approximately equal to the footprint, calculated as x=0.24H, and the Ka band resolution being 39m. This results in a processed product ready for user application.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the accurate collection of microwave radiometric data at varying frequencies and polarizations in remote sensing applications?
Enablement.Answer: The use of K and Ka band airborne microwave radiometers allowed the collection of radiometric data at frequencies of 18.7GHz and 36.0GHz, respectively. The Ka band employed scanning imaging with vertical polarization, while the K band conducted zenith angle observations without polarization information. These technological advancements enabled precise data collection in challenging conditions, such as varying flight altitudes and speeds.
